metadata.title: Palladium coordinated in N-heterocyclic carbene-functionalized porous organic polymer for efficient oxidative carbonylation of glycerol

Short communication Palladium coordinated in N-heterocyclic carbene-functionalized porous organic polymer for efficient oxidative carbonylation of glycerol Yizhu Lei Conceptualization Investigation Methodology Writing - review & editing a ⁎ Guosong Lan Investigation Formal analysis Writing - original draft a Meitao Fan Validation Investigation a Guangxing Li Supervision Writing - review & editing b ⁎ a School of Chemistry and Materials Engineering, Liupanshui Normal University, Liupanshui, Guizhou 553004, PR China School of Chemistry and Materials Engineering Liupanshui Normal University Liupanshui Guizhou 553004 PR China School of Chemistry and Materials Engineering, Liupanshui Normal University, Liupanshui, Guizhou 553004, PR China b Jingchu University of Technology, Jingmen, Hubei 448000, PR China Jingchu University of Technology Jingmen Hubei 448000 PR China Jingchu University of Technology, Jingmen, Hubei 448000, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Palladium coordinated in N-heterocyclic carbene-functionalized porous organic polymer (Pd@PQP-NHC) was successfully prepared via a facile copolymerization and successive immobilization method. The obtained Pd@PQP-NHC that featured relatively large surface area, hierarchical pore structure, and strong electron interaction between Pd species and bis-NHC ligand, displayed very high catalytic activity for the oxidative carbonylation of glycerol. A 0.025 mol% of Pd loading was sufficient for 96% conversion of glycerol with a high turnover frequency (TOF) of 1901 h−1. Moreover, the catalyst could be reused at least nine consecutive recycles without obvious loss of its initial activity. Graphical abstract Unlabelled Image Keywords Oxidative carbonylation Glycerol Glycerol carbonate Porous organic polymers N-heterocyclic carbene 1 Introduction Biodiesel has gained growing industrial attention recently as one of the most important renewable energy sources in the word [1]. However, massive glycerol was produced as a main by-product with the rapid increment of biodiesel production, and thus resulting in the increasing stock and dropping price of glycerol [2]. In this context, the applications of glycerol as a low-cost feedstock for the preparation of useful derivatives urgently need to be developed [3]. Nowadays, numerous strategies for the conversions of glycerol to valuable glycerol derivatives have been developed [4–6]. Among various glycerol derivatives, glycerol carbonate is considered as one of the most attractive derivatives due to its broad range of applications, such as green solvent, personal care, carries of batteries and polymer intermediates [5,6]. To date, a number of synthetic routes for the conversion of glycerol into glycerol carbonate have been developed [5,6]. Among them, oxidative carbonylation of glycerol with CO and O2 is an attractive route because its following advantages: (i) the low prices of raw materials, (ii) the relatively high activity of CO and O2, (iii) the nice atom economy (87%), and (iv) the green byproduct (water) [7,8]. The key points for the oxidative carbonylation of glycerol lie in the development of efficient catalysts. To this end, a number of transition metal catalytic systems, such as homogeneous PdCl2(phen)/KI [8], Pd(OAc)2/Mn(acac)3/KBr [9], PdI2/KI [10] and CuCl2 [11], have been developed. Nevertheless, the reported homogeneous catalyst systems suffered from some drawbacks, such as the problems of product separation and catalyst reuse, and unsatisfactory catalytic activity. Therefore, it is desirable to develop highly efficient heterogeneous catalysts to address these drawbacks. Towards this end, we developed zeolite-Y-confined Pd complex (PdCl2(phen)@Y) [12] as a recyclable catalyst for the oxidative carbonylation of glycerol, with which a TOF of 317 h−1 was obtained. Dong et al. [13] reported that Pd/C with the aid of NaI could afford 82.2% conversion of glycerol with a high TOF of 900 h−1. These results demonstrated the efficiency of heterogeneous Pd catalysts in the oxidative carbonylation reaction of glycerol. However, the activity and reusability of the currently available solid catalysts are still unsatisfactory. Therefore, it is still a challenge to develop highly active and stable heterogeneous catalysts for the oxidative carbonylation of glycerol. Porous organic polymers (POPs) have recently appeared as attractive materials for developing heterogeneous catalysts because of their large surface areas and designable chemical functionalities [14–16]. At present, various synthetic methods, such as Friedel-Crafts reaction, free radical polymerization, Sonogashira coupling and alkyne trimerization, have been developed for the fabrication of POPs [16]. Among them, POPs that synthesized by solvothermal and free radical polymerization method are particularly appropriate for developing heterogeneous catalyst on account of their simple synthesis, hierarchical pore structure, flexible frameworks, excellent swelling properties [16,17]. As a result, porous catalysts fabricated by such method exhibit the characters of quasi-homogeneous catalysis, and thus showing comparable, or even higher catalytic activities than their homogeneous analogues [16,18]. On the other hand, N-heterocyclic carbene-metal (NHC-M) complexes have been widely applied as stable and active catalysts for a wide variety of organic reactions [19,20,21]. For facilitating catalyst separation and recycling, NHC-M complexes immobilized on various supports such as organic polymer [22,23], inorganic silica [24], and POPs [25–28], have been reported. Among them, POPs supported NHC-M catalysts attracted our attention because of their high surface areas and easy accessibility towards organic substrates [28]. Recently, a number of POPs supported NHC-M catalysts have been developed via Friedel-Crafts reactions [25–28]. However, up to date, POPs supported NHC-M catalysts that prepared by solvothermal and free radical polymerization method have been extremely limited [29]. On the other hand, palladium NHC complexes (Pd-NHC) have displayed high activities in various carbonylation reactions [30], nevertheless, their applications in the oxidative carbonylation of glycerol to glycerol carbonate have been rarely reported. In light of superior performances of the di- or poly-NHC metal complexes over mono NHC analogues [31,32] and the advantages of solvothermal and free radical polymerization method, herein, we designed and prepared a new porous organic polymer supported bis-chelating NHC-Pd catalyst (Pd@PQP-NHC) via a facile solvothermal and free radical copolymerization method. This porous bis-chelating NHC-Pd catalyst proved to be an active, robust and recyclable catalyst for oxidative carbonylation of glycerol. 2 Experimental section Please see Supplementary material. 3 Results 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of Pd@PQP-NHC Porous organic polymer supported bis-chelating NHC-Pd catalyst, Pd@PQP-NHC, was prepared via a facile solvothermal and free radical copolymerization of tetra-vinylphosphonium salt and bis-vinylimidazolium salt, followed by chelating palladium species in DMSO solvent (Scheme 1 ). The tetra-vinylphosphonium salt monomer acted as a crosslinking agent [33,34], while the bis-vinylimidazolium salt monomer was used as the precursor of NHC ligand. ICP analysis revealed that the palladium content of Pd@PQP-NHC was 2.49 wt%. As shown in Table S1, PQP-NHC had a BET surface area of 323 m2·g−1 and a pore volume of 0.71 cm3/g. After immobilization of palladium species, the resultant Pd@PQP-NHC showed a decreased BET surface area of 234 m2·g−1 and a reducing pore volume of 0.57 cm3/g. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of PQP-NHC and Pd@PQP-NHC were depicted in Fig. 1 . The two samples exhibited similar sorption behavior. The steep steps of adsorption curves at P/P 0 < 0.01 regions indicated the filling of micropore, the hysteresis loops of the isotherms at P/P 0 = 0.6–1.0 regions suggested the abundance of mesopore, while the sharp rise at P/P 0 = 0.9–1.0 regions illustrated the presence of macropores. Consistently, pore-size distribution curve of Pd@PQP-NHC (Fig. 1, insert) also demonstrated the presence of micropore and mesopore. SEM and TEM images of PQP-NHC and Pd@PQP-NHC were shown in Fig. S2. The results revealed that the samples had similar porous morphology which was composed of small and loosely aggregated particles. Fig. 2 showed the FT-IR spectra of QP, [C1DVIM]Br, PQP-NHC, and Pd@PQP-NHC. The spectra of PQP-NHC and Pd@PQP-NHC in Fig. 2(c) and (d) showed the characteristic peaks at 2930 and 2850 cm−1, corresponding to CH stretching vibrations of the saturated methane. Compared to the monomers in Fig. 2(a) and (b), the CH (>3000 cm−1) vibrations of the terminal CCH2 groups were absent in Fig. 2(c) and (d). These findings suggested that the free-radical copolymerization reaction of the monomers was finished. In addition, the characteristic peak of imidazolium salts at around 1170 cm−1 was weakened dramatically in spectrum of Pd@PQP-NHC, while a new peak at 1260 cm−1 appeared. These findings should be attributed to the formation NHC-metal complexes. Solid-state 13C NMR spectra of PQP-NHC and Pd@PQP-NHC were depicted in Fig. 3 . The spectra displayed a series of bands at around 120–152 and 20–60 ppm, which corresponded respectively to the aromatic carbons and the polymerized vinyl carbons of the polymers [18,34]. Meanwhile, Pd@PQP-NHC showed a small band at 190.1 ppm, which might be attributed to signals of CNHC [26]. Thus, these observations further demonstrated the successful preparation of Pd@PQP-NHC. XPS analysis of Pd@PQP-NHC catalyst was shown in Fig. S3. As shown in Fig. S3, XPS full spectra of the Pd@PQP-NHC confirmed the presence of P, C, Pd and N elements. Pd3d XPS spectrum of the Pd@PQP-NHC showed two peaks at 343.0 and 337.9 eV, indicating that Pd species in Pd@PQP-NHC was Pd2+ rather than metallic Pd. Compared to the homogeneous Pd(OAc)2 (338.4 eV eV) [35], the binding energy of Pd 3d5/2 in Pd@PQP-NHC showed a red shift by 0.5 eV. This red shift could be assigned to the strong electron-donating property of the bis-NHC ligand. Thermostability analysis of Pd@PQP-NHC in Fig. S4 suggested that Pd@PQP-NHC could be stable at least 200 °C. 3.2 Catalytic performance With the expected catalyst in hand, catalytic performance of the obtained Pd@PQP-NHC catalyst was tested in the oxidative carbonylation of glycerol with CO and O2. As shown in Table 1 , with KI as a promoter, the prepared Pd@PQP-NHC showed much higher catalytic activity than the homogeneous PdCl2(phen) and commercial Pd/C, achieving a TOF number of 416 h−1 that was about 3.3 and 5.7 times of that of PdCl2(phen) and Pd/C, respectively (Table 1, entries 1–3). Previous investigations [12,13] indicated that the halide promoter had great influence on the catalytic activity. Therefore, several typical halides were screened. Among them, (CH4)4NI afforded the best performance (Table 1, entry 5), this might be attributed to its good solubility in DMA. With a molar ratio of (CH4)4NI/Pd at 15, a higher catalytic activity was obtained (Table 1, entry 6). However, further increasing the amount of (CH4)4NI, a similar conversion of glycerol was preserved (Table 1, entry 7). The influence of reaction temperature on the catalytic performance of the Pd@PQP-NHC was investigated over a temperature range of 100–160 °C. As shown in Table 2 , with the temperature rising from 100 to 140 °C (Table 2, entries 1–5), the conversions of glycerol and TOF numbers gradually increased, achieving a 97% conversion of glycerol and a 99% selectivity of glycerol carbonate at 140 °C. Further increasing the reaction temperature to 150 °C (Table 2, entries 6 and 7), a slight decrease in the selectivity was observed. Then, the effect of catalyst loading on the catalytic performance of Pd@PQP-NHC was investigated at 140 °C. Noticeably, with a molar ratio of glycerol/Pd at 4000, a 96% conversion of glycerol with a record-high TOF number of 1901 h−1 was obtained after prolonging the reaction time to 2 h (Table 2, entry 9). With these optimal conditions in hand, the effect of CO/O2 mole ratio on the oxidative carbonylation of glycerol was also investigated (Table S3, supplementary material). The results suggested that the conversion of glycerol decreased gradually with increasing the partial pressure ratio of CO/O2. On the other hand, comparison results of Pd@PQP-NHC with some Pd-based catalysts reported previously were also listed in Table 2. Obviously, under similar or even milder reaction conditions, the prepared Pd@PQP-NHC herein showed much higher catalytic activities than that of the previously reported PdCl2(phen)@Y and Pd/C catalysts (Table 2, entries 10 and 11). 3.3 Recycling experiment The recyclability of Pd@PQP-NHC catalyst in the oxidative carbonylation of glycerol was evaluated. To facilitate the recycling of the solid catalyst, the catalytic reaction was conducted in scaled-up quantities. As shown in Fig. 4 , with three times of glycerol amount, a 94% conversion of glycerol was still obtained in the first catalytic run. After reusing for nine times, Pd@PQP-NHC was still capable of promoting the carbonylation reaction in an 85% conversion of glycerol with a TOF of 1683 h−1. Pd leaching in the filtrate of each catalytic run was also analyzed by ICP analysis. A 1.06 ppm of Pd leaching was observed for the first catalytic run. After the first catalytic run, negligible Pd leaching (<0.1 ppm) was observed. Moreover, ICP analysis revealed that 95.8% Pd species was still retained in the recycling Pd@PQP-NHC after reusing nine times. Additionally, TEM and XPS analyses of the recycled Pd@PQP-NHC (Fig. S5) suggested that no obvious morphology change and formation of Pd particles after reusing nine times. Also, a hot filtration test was carried out to determine whether the catalytic activity was derived from the solid Pd@PQP-NHC or the leaching palladium species. Under the optimal reaction conditions, a fresh Pd@PQP-NHC catalyzed oxidative carbonylation of glycerol was stopped after 0.5 h at 140 °C, when the yield of glycerol carbonate reached to 39%. Pd@PQP-NHC was immediately separated from the reaction mixture by a high-speed centrifugation (20,000 r/min, 2 min), and then, a part of the hot liquid (about 15 ml) mixture was allowed to react a further 1 h under the same conditions. The results suggested that about 40% yield of glycerol carbonate was obtained. Thus, these results suggested that the prepared Pd@PQP-NHC is a highly active, stable and recyclable catalyst for the oxidative carbonylation of glycerol. 4 Conclusions A porous organic polymer supported bis-chelating NHC-Pd catalyst was synthesized via a simple solvothermal copolymerization and successive immobilization method. The obtained Pd@PQP-NHC catalyst displayed outstanding catalytic activity in the oxidative carbonylation of glycerol to glycerol carbonate. A 0.025 mol% of Pd loading was sufficient for high conversion of glycerol with a record-high turnover frequency (TOF) of 1901 h−1. Importantly, the Pd@PQP-NHC catalyst could be easily recovered and reused nine times without significant loss of catalytic activity. Also, the catalyst showed negligible Pd leaching after the first catalytic run, and 95.8% Pd species was still retained after reusing nine times. In terms of the excellent activity, stability, and recyclability, the Pd@PQP-NHC emerge as efficient solid catalyst for the conversion of glycerol, and therefore, showing promising and broad applications for chemical industry. coredata.dc:description: Palladium coordinated in N-heterocyclic carbene-functionalized porous organic polymer (Pd@PQP-NHC) was successfully prepared via a facile copolymerization and successive immobilization method. The obtained Pd@PQP-NHC that featured relatively large surface area, hierarchical pore structure, and strong electron interaction between Pd species and bis-NHC ligand, displayed very high catalytic activity for the oxidative carbonylation of glycerol. A 0.025 mol% of Pd loading was sufficient for 96% conversion of glycerol with a high turnover frequency (TOF) of 1901 h−1. Moreover, the catalyst could be reused at least nine consecutive recycles without obvious loss of its initial activity.
coredata.dc:title: Palladium coordinated in N-heterocyclic carbene-functionalized porous organic polymer for efficient oxidative carbonylation of glycerol
